deliberation: The verse narrates movement ('he led me') and gives exact architectural measurements of jambs and width of the 'tent' (הָאֹהֶל). I checked whether 'tent' is being used metaphorically for the temple as a whole, but here it functions as a technical architectural term within a visionary but internally literal description. No metaphors, similes, personification, merism, or idioms beyond technical vocabulary are present.

This verse continues precise dimensional data (width of entrance, flanking walls, length and width of the hall). The language is strictly descriptive and spatial. I checked for any use of numbers or dimensions as hyperbolic or symbolic (e.g., 40, 20), but in this context they are blueprint-like, not figurative. No figurative devices are employed.

Again the focus is on entering an inner room and measuring doorway elements (jambs, entrance width). I considered whether 'inner' (לִפְנִימָה) or 'entrance' might carry metaphorical connotations of access to God, but here they clearly denote physical spatial relations in a vision of architectural layout. Therefore, no figurative language is detected.

The text reports dimensions of the inner space and identifies it as 'קֹדֶשׁ הַקֳּדָשִׁים' ('Holy of Holies'). This phrase is a standard superlative construct/technical cultic term for the innermost sanctuary, not a live metaphor or simile; it does not compare to another domain but intensifies 'holy' within the same semantic field. I judged this to be lexicalized terminology rather than figurative language.

The verse describes wall thickness and width of side-chambers all around the house. I examined the repetition of סָבִיב סָבִיב ('all around') to see if it functioned as merism or hyperbole for completeness, but here it literally describes encircling architecture. The language is technical and spatial, not figurative.

Verse 6 details the arrangement of side chambers 'one above another' in thirty-three instances and explains how they are supported by projections in the wall. I considered whether 'being held' (אֲחוּזִים) might be metaphorical, but within architectural engineering this is a literal description of attachment. No cross-domain comparisons or personification appear.

This verse explains the widening of the structure from story to story because of winding passages and how one ascends from bottom to top via the middle. Words like 'ascend' (יַעֲלֶה) can elsewhere be metaphorical, but here they clearly refer to moving between physical stories by stair-like passages. I found no metaphor, simile, or symbolic idiom beyond literal architecture.

The verse observes a raised pavement or foundation around the house and gives its measured height. I checked whether 'height around the house' could be hyperbolic for grandeur, but the mention of exact measure (six cubits) signals literal description. No figurative language is used.

Here the outer wall thickness of the side chamber and the walk between side chambers is described. The terms are spatial and structural. I considered whether 'that which served as a walk' might be metonymic, but it straightforwardly names a functional space. No figurative expressions are present.

Verse 10 gives the width of the space between chamber complexes and the house, repeated 'all around.' As in similar verses, this is a geometrical description without cross-domain mapping or exaggeration. No metaphor, simile, metonymy, or other figures appear.

The verse specifies entrances to the side chambers (north and south) and the width of the walk. The directional language (north, south) is purely geographic here. I assessed whether these directions might function symbolically, but in this context they operate as literal orientation markers. No figurative language detected.

This verse continues spatial detailing of a building to the west of the reserved space—its width, wall thickness, and length. Although western orientation has symbolic resonance elsewhere, the verse itself merely reports measurements. I found no idiom, metaphor, or personification.

The total length of the house and of the reserved space plus structures and walls is given as 100 cubits. Round numbers like 100 can sometimes be symbolic or hyperbolic, but here they are embedded within a systematic architectural scheme with other exact numbers. The usage is literal rather than hyperbolic or figurative.

The verse states that the front of the house and the reserved space on the east are 100 cubits wide. Again, this continues the exact measurement schema. No metaphorical comparisons, idioms, or personifications are present.

This verse measures the length/width of the structure facing the reserved space and mentions inner hall and portico. I noted that comparisons or similes could have appeared here but do not; it is strictly descriptive. The rare term וְאַתִּיקֶיהָא (its galleries/ledges) is technical, not idiomatic in a figurative sense.

The verse details thresholds, shuttered windows, galleries, and wood panelling from floor up to the windows. I considered whether 'covering' the windows might be metaphorical for hiddenness, but in context it clearly describes physical construction. No rhetorical figures like metaphor, simile, or personification are employed.

Here woodwork extends above the opening and over 'all the wall' inside and outside, with 'measurements' or 'patterns' (מִדּוֹת) described. I checked whether this might indicate symbolic order or perfection figuratively, but lexically and syntactically it functions as literal ornamentation/specification on the walls. No figurative language is evident.

Cherubim and palm trees carved on the walls, with palm between cherub and cherub and two faces to each cherub, are described. While cherubim and palms are theologically symbolic motifs, the verbal description is of literal carvings; the verse does not linguistically treat something non-cherubic as a cherub, etc. I therefore classify the symbolism as iconographic rather than as verbal figurative language in this verse.

The verse explains that each cherub has a human face and a lion's face oriented toward palm trees on either side. The imagery is striking but still a description of depicted composite beings, consistent with Ezekiel's visionary iconography. No simile ('like'), metaphor (X is Y across domains), or personification (non-person acting as person) is present beyond the ontological status of cherubs within the vision.

Cherubim and palm trees are said to be 'made' from floor to above the entrance on the wall of the temple. This reiterates full vertical coverage. I checked whether 'from the earth to above the entrance' functioned as hyperbole for totality, but given the defined architectural limits (floor/door-top), it is literal spatial extent, not an open-ended exaggeration.

The verse notes that the nave had squared doorposts and that the appearance of the holy place was 'like the appearance' (הַמַּרְאֶה כַּמַּרְאֶה). This comparison is intra-domain (one architectural appearance to another) and functions as a statement of sameness/consistency, not as a figurative simile bridging different conceptual domains. It is best read as literal visual similarity, so I do not classify it as figurative.

This verse uniquely introduces cultic terminology alongside architectural description. A wooden object is first called 'the altar' (הַמִּזְבֵּחַ) and then identified with the declaration 'This is the table that is before YHWH' (זֶה הַשֻּׁלְחָן אֲשֶׁר לִפְנֵי יְהוָה). Here 'table' is a non-literal designation for an altar, drawing on the domain of dining to conceptualize sacrificial worship. Additionally, the phrase 'before YHWH' is a fixed cultic idiom/metonymy for God's localized presence. I therefore identify two distinct figurative expressions in this verse.

target: the wooden altar in the inner sanctuary
ground: both altar and table are places where food/gifts are placed before a superior/host
shared function of presenting/meals and fellowship
social-ritual interaction with deity conceived in meal terms
posture: the speaker (interpreting guide) positively frames sacrificial altar as YHWH’s table, emphasizing covenant fellowship rather than mere slaughter
interpretive/theological stance highlighting intimacy and hospitality
worship theology and covenant relationship domain
instances.explanation: The term 'table' is metaphorically applied to the altar, importing the imagery of a dining table to conceptualize sacrifices as a meal set before God, thus recasting cultic slaughter in terms of fellowship and hospitality.

target: God’s cultic presence in the sanctuary where sacrifices are offered
theological-cultic domain of God's localized dwelling
vehicle: spatial position 'in front of' a person of high status
ground: to stand or place something 'before' a king signifies access, favor, and presentation for acceptance
association of spatial proximity with relational favor and official audience
shared royal-cultic concept of appearing in the presence of a sovereign
posture: the idiom assumes and affirms that YHWH is truly present in the sanctuary to receive offerings, using courtly language to describe cultic reality
reverential stance portraying worship as an audience with the divine King
cultic theology of God as enthroned monarch receiving gifts
instances.explanation: The phrase 'before YHWH' is a fixed cultic idiom in which spatial language stands metonymically for access to and favor with God’s royal presence in the sanctuary, drawing on the courtly practice of standing before a king.

deliberation: The verse notes that both the hall and the holy place had double doors. This is straightforward architectural description. I checked for any idiomatic use of 'doors' as metonymy for access to God, but in this immediate context they are literal doors of the building.

Here the mechanics of the double doors are explained: each door has two turning leaves. The language remains fully technical and concrete, with no evident figurative extensions such as personifying the doors or using them symbolically in the discourse.

Cherubim and palm trees are said to be carved on the doors just as on the walls, and a wooden lattice is mentioned. As with verses 18–20, these motifs are symbolically rich iconography, but the verse itself simply reports literal carvings and external latticework. No metaphor, simile, or other figure is applied linguistically to some different target.

The final verse notes shuttered windows and palm trees on the side walls of the portico, on the house’s side-chambers, and on the projecting structures. Again, while palm imagery may symbolize flourishing or righteousness elsewhere, here the text just inventories decorative elements. The language is purely descriptive, with no explicit figurative usage.
